pegasus: – Republicans are expected to keep control of more than two-thirds of the nation's governor's offices tonight. Republicans currently hold 29 governorships, Democrats have 20, and Rhode Island's Lincoln Chafee is an Independent, NPR reports. In fact, Republicans are on track to increase their numbers by at least one, with the potential to extend their hold to more than two-thirds of the nation's top state offices. Eight of the gubernatorial seats up for grabs are now held by Democrats; three are in Republican hands. Polls and race analysts suggest that only three of tonight's races are considered competitive, all in states where incumbent Democratic governors aren't running again: Montana, New Hampshire, and Washington. While those state races remain too close to call, Republicans are expected to wrest the North Carolina governorship from Democratic control, and to easily win GOP-held seats in Utah, North Dakota, and Indiana. Democrats are likely to hold on to their seats in West Virginia and Missouri, and are expected to notch safe wins in races for seats they hold in Vermont and Delaware. – Facebook removed a photo of two men kissing from a London Facebook page that promoted a "gay kiss-in" protest, the New York Times reports. Dozens of people posted their own photos of same-sex couples kissing in protest after the photo was removed, prompting Facebook to issue an apology. "The photo in question does not violate our Statement of Rights and Responsibilities and was removed in error," the company said in a statement. "We apologize for the inconvenience." The Facebook page was set up to protest the removal of a same-sex couple from a London pub for kissing. The organizer of the "kiss-in" event, however, says the page was not blocked by Facebook but made private by him and his organization.

– Siskiyou County in rural Northern California wants to leave the state. The county board of supervisors voted 4-1 on Tuesday to pursue secession from California, the Redding Record Searchlight reports. More than 100 people attended the meeting, many of them in support of the move, which would create a new state called Jefferson. "Many proposed laws are unconstitutional and deny us our God-given rights," said one resident. "We need our own state so we can make laws that fit our way of life." Siskiyou would join neighboring counties in Northern California and Southern Oregon in the new state. "I was one of the people who thinks the state of Jefferson wasn't a bad idea," said a Humboldt County supervisor. "There has been a total lack of respect of our water rights and the fire fee. Those things may not be important to the rest of the state, but it's important to us." The Los Angeles Times notes that efforts to secede from California date back to the 1800s.

– Microsoft today confirmed it's buying Nokia in a Nokia-related deal worth some Nokia-esque $7.3 billion. Here's what you need to know about the deal, which comes just days after Steve Ballmer stepped down as Microsoft CEO: The move is a smart one for Microsoft, writes Rolfe Winkler in the Wall Street Journal. The company is now "poised to adopt a vertically integrated strategy more akin to Apple's," he writes, but the real test will come when the two companies work together to create a more complete mobile experience for customers. The deal is a good one for Microsoft, writes Henry Blodget at Business Insider, but he warns that it's also a bad one for Nokia. The company has lost its lead in the smartphone market to both Apple and Google, and the deal will make it more difficult for Nokia to compete. Microsoft has been working on a devices and services strategy for a while now, and the Nokia deal is the latest step in that direction, writes Dan Nosowitz at ZDNet. "Own the desktop (via Windows) and building additional services on top, like Office or search, has been vital for Microsoft's strategy until now, so as our interest shifts from the desktop to the tablet or smartphone

– The Supreme Court kicks off its new term today, and there are a lot of high-profile cases on the docket. Here's a look at some of the ones that could come to the court's attention: Abortion: The court could rule as soon as next month on whether states can regulate abortion clinics, the New York Times reports. A lower court had already struck down a key part of California's law, but the high court could order a new round of appeals. Abortion: The court could rule as soon as next month on a challenge to President Obama's executive order on immigration, Politico reports. A lower court had already blocked the president's plan, but it's unclear whether that will hold up this term or if Obama's plan will be put on hold until after the president leaves office.  affirmative action: The court could rule on the constitutionality of Texas' affirmative action program, which uses race as a factor in college admissions. The last time the case came before the court, Anthony Kennedy voted with the other six justices to say the program was too narrow, but this time around, he could join the four other Republican appointees to set a higher bar. – A preservationist says he's found evidence that a Manhattan building is the former site of an 18th-century tavern where George Washington is believed to have enjoyed a celebratory drink during the American Revolution. If it is indeed the home of the legendary watering hole, the discovery could mean that the building that is perhaps Manhattan's oldest is slated to demolished. “After the English had marched up the Bowery and out of the city (in 1783), George Washington and Governor (George) Clinton stopped at the Bull’s Head (tavern),” preservationist Adam Woodward told WCBS 880’s Alex Silverman. Legend had it that “the Bull’s Head’s structure, cellar, bones” were still inside, Woodward said. He decided to poke around and, in the basement, Woodward found what he believes are Colonial-era, hand-hewn, and hand-planed joists and foundation walls. “Found myself in what I am pretty certain is the 1750s historic tavern,” he said. Woodward said he felt compelled to investigate in the building, which once housed a chain drugstore and the Atlantic Garden beer garden, because time was running out. “I just realized that it would be the last chance to solve one of the great mysteries of New York

– The Israeli air force shot down a drone that infiltrated its airspace over the weekend, and an Iranian military official says the incident shows that Israel's Iron Dome defense system "does not work and lacks the necessary capacity," Reuters reports. Jamaluddin Aberoumand, deputy coordinator for Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, said the incident indicated that Israel's Iron Dome "does not work and lacks the necessary capacity" to deal with missiles. "The Zionist regime (Israel) has many enemies," he added. The Israeli air force released a 10-second video clip of what it said was Saturday's mid-air interception, showing a small aircraft just before a missile from a fighter jet destroys it. The drone was first spotted above the Mediterranean near the Hamas-ruled Gaza Strip to the west of Israel, said military spokeswoman Avital Leibovich. An Israeli parliament member wrote on Twitter it was an "Iranian drone launched by Hezbollah," referring to the Lebanese Shi'ite group that fought a war with Israel in 2006. Israeli defense officials have not confirmed or deny them. The Iron Dome system, jointly funded with the US, is designed to shoot down short-range guerrilla rockets, not slow-flying aircraft. It intercepted more than 80% of the targets it engaged in

– "A lost treasure has been found," US Attorney Loretta Lynch said Thursday in a statement announcing the return of a Picasso painting stolen from a Paris museum more than a decade ago. The 1911 cubist painting "La Coiffeuse," which translates to "The Hairdresser," was discovered in December in a FedEx shipment from Belgium to Newark, NJ, the New York Times reports. According to NBC News, the painting had been bequeathed to France's National Museum by a former director, but museum staff discovered it was missing in 2001 when they received a loan request for it. It was valued at more than $2.5 million at the time, the AP reports. The sender of the December shipment was identified only as "Robert," who mailed the painting to a climate-controlled storage facility in Queens. The painting was seized by the Department of Homeland Security, and Lynch filed a civil complaint to return it to France. "The market to sell stolen antiquities in the United States is drying up," a Homeland Security Investigations agent said in a statement. The Picasso will be on display at the Pompidou Center in Paris until May. The director says the discovery is a "true comfort" at a time when the cultural world is reeling from an Islamic State video showing the destruction of statues in Iraq.

– If you're looking for the best burger in St. Paul, check out this list from the St. Paul Pioneer Press. It's "the best burger in town. Really, it's that amazing. Not a huge place, so don't bring your whole extended family with you." And if that doesn't strike your fancy, head to one of the other three on the list: Que Viet in Minneapolis, which has the best egg rolls in the state, reports WCCO. (Click for the complete list, which also includes the best distilleries in Minneapolis.)

– A Dallas police officer who was shot while responding to a call at a Home Depot has died, the Dallas Morning News reports. Officer Rogelio Santander was shot in the back of the head around 4pm Tuesday while responding to a call at the North Dallas store. He was taken to a hospital, and fellow officer Crystal Almeida was shot in the face. A store employee and a security guard also were shot, CBS DFW reports. All three victims are making "remarkable recoveries," Dallas Police Chief U. Renee Hall said at a news conference Wednesday. The suspect, 29-year-old Armando Juarez, was arrested late Tuesday. He was initially charged with aggravated assault against a public servant and aggravated assault against a civilian, but a capital murder charge was added Wednesday morning after Santander's death. The district attorney's office has assigned a team of attorneys to prosecute Juarez in "pursuit of justice," District Attorney Faith Johnson said in a written statement.

– The US Coast Guard says it's looking for a man who has cost the service about $500,000 after responding to nearly 30 of his fake distress calls, the AP reports. In a press release published Friday, the Coast Guard says the 28 calls have originated from around the area of Annapolis, Maryland. Each call involved the same male voice and used an emergency radio channel. He's been making the calls since July 2014. The two most recent calls were made on the night of July 21 and the early morning of July 22. The Coast Guard also says hoax calls distract rescuers from real emergencies, putting both the public and the responding crews at risk. "A hoax call is a deadly and serious offense," says Lt. Cmdr. Sara Wallace. "Calls like these not only put our crews at risk, but they put the lives of the public at risk." Making false distress calls is a felony, punishable by up to six years in prison, a $10,000 civil fine, $250,000 criminal fine, and a reimbursement to the Coast Guard for their efforts, the Coast Guard says.

– The Obama campaign sent out a mailer in Ohio that looks a lot like an online cat meme—but it's not actually about cats. Instead, it's about getting people to vote early. "STOP LOOKING AT CATS ONLINE AND GO VOTE," reads the flyer, which was spotted by Reddit user MollyBloom11. The Obama campaign confirmed that the mailer is real and has been used in Ohio, but it's not clear whether similar images have been used elsewhere. Meanwhile, Politico reports that Hollywood stars Jake Gyllenhaal, Zach Galifianakis, Renee Zellweger, Susan Saint James Ebersol, and Amanda Seyfried have donated at least four figures to both campaigns in the final hours of the campaign.

– Police in Huntington Beach, Calif., are investigating the shooting deaths of two brothers as a possible murder-suicide. Officers found the bodies of Benjamin Ullestad, 25, and Brandon Ullestad, 22, just before 3pm Sunday in the apartment they shared, the Los Angeles Times reports. "We don't know," a police spokeswoman says. "We're not ruling (murder-suicide) out. We're not ruling out an accident-suicide. But we are not looking for any outstanding suspects." A handgun was found at the scene, CBS Los Angeles reports. It was unclear who made the distressed call from inside the home that led police to the apartment, which is close to Marina High School, the baseball fields of Marina Park, and Helen Murphy Branch Library.

– In the wake of the Benghazi attack, the Obama administration has been under fire for its initial response—specifically, its 94-word "talking points" on the attack. But the New York Times takes a closer look at those talking points, and finds that they were heavily edited. For one thing, they didn't include any mention of al-Qaeda. For another, they didn't include any details of the attack on the US consulate in Libya, which is what killed Ambassador Chris Stevens. And they didn't include any details of the attack on the US ambassador to Libya, which is what killed him. And they didn't include any details of the attack on the consulate in Tripoli, which is what killed him. The 94-word summary emerged from a daylong email debate between more than two dozen intelligence officials, in which they contested and whittled the available evidence into a bland summary with no reference to al-Qaeda, an assessment the administration now acknowledges was wide of the mark. The Times also takes a look at the State Department's response to the attack, and finds that it "did little to mollify critics"—including John Kerry, who called it a "cover-up" in an interview last week.

– An erupting volcano has created a new island in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Tonga. The volcano has been erupting for a month in the ocean about 40 miles northwest of the capital, Nuku'alofa. Last week it disrupted international air travel to the Pacific archipelago for several days. New Zealand volcanologist Nico Fournier said he traveled by boat to within about a mile of the new island on Saturday to take a closer look. He said it's made mainly of loose scoria and its dimensions are about 1.1 miles by 0.9 miles, and that it rises about 109 yards above the sea. "It's quite an exciting site, you get to see the birth of an island," he tells the AP. "Visually it was quite spectacular, but there was no big sound coming with it, no boom. It was a bit eerie." He said that once the volcano stops erupting, it will likely take the ocean no more than a few months to erode the island entirely. He said it would need to be made of lava or something more durable to survive. Fournier, who works for New Zealand agency GNS Science, said he was able to establish that the volcano was mainly belching steam into the atmosphere, and that the small amount of ash

– The number of children in the US who rely on food stamps has spiked since the start of the Great Recession, according to a US Census Bureau survey released yesterday. In 2007, before the recession began, about 9 million children were living with married parents who received food stamps, or about one in eight, the New York Times reports. "The rate of children living with married parents who receive food stamps has doubled since 2007," the Census Bureau says. The number of people using food stamps has almost doubled since the start of the recession, to nearly 48 million in 2013, but only dipped a little last year, to about 46 million people, the Times reports. The median age for people first getting married in 2014 was 29 for men and 27 for women, Reuters reports. The number of marriages also shrank last year, from three-quarters in 1940 to less than half in 2014, and the median age for people first getting married in 2014 was 29 for men and 27 for women, up from 24 and 21 in 1947. The number of children living in single-parent homes also jumped, from 27% in 1960 to 27% last year, Reuters reports. The Census Bureau's 2014 Current Population Survey analyzed data on families and living arrangements for more than 60 years. (In 2012, Newt Gingrich

– A deaf woman was able to order two drinks at a Starbucks drive-thru in St. Augustine, Fla., using sign language, the Florida Times-Union reports. Rebecca King posted a video to Facebook Tuesday showing her waiting in her seat at the drive-thru window while a woman says, "Hi, welcome to Starbucks. What can we get started for you today?" King doesn't respond, but a barista appears on a monitor and begins to communicate with King using sign language. "Starbucks! This is what I'm talking about!" King writes in her Facebook post. "Share it away! We can change the world!" The video has been viewed more than 5 million times since King posted it, Action News Jax reports. "I think it's awesome because it gives the deaf opportunity to order in a different way through the window," says Tiri Fellows, a professor who is deaf and teaches American Sign Language. "It's about time," she says. "My friends from Arizona saw that on Facebook, Illinois Texas—they all reposted that video."

– Conch shells are an important part of Florida Keys culture. Native-born islanders are called Conchs, and the Keys are nicknamed the Conch Republic. Empty conch shells, which produce a unique sound when blown, have also been used as signaling devices in the Florida Keys for centuries. USA Today reports Diana Fiscal-Gonzalez of Dallas was planning to give the state-protected mollusks away as gifts when she was arrested for taking 40 queen conchs seashells from a beach in Key West. She pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 15 days in jail, six months of probation, a $500 fine, and $268 in court costs. A Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission officer reported seeing three containers full of queen conches soaking in bleach and water when he met with Fiscal-Gonzalez, who said she didn't know she was illegal to take the shells.

"Christie and I have talked recently and I have privately apologized to her, but, given the public nature of their divorce and custody battle, I feel a public apology is also appropriate and deserved," Shaw writes. In 2012, Shaw said "it was the black cloud of Christie Brinkley’s hate" that caused her marriage to Peter Cook to fall apart, when Cook had actually been cheating on Brinkley with his 18-year-old assistant. "Christie was wrongly vilified as being an embittered ex-wife," Shaw continues. "I now believe she had every right to do what she did by taking a public stand; she was only trying to protect her children and have the truth be told. Given the nature of Peter’s behavior, and battles for sole custody of their children, it was necessary for her to confront him publicly." Sources tell Page Six that Shaw was the one to end things with Cook, 55, this year. – Tonight's GOP debate in Michigan is the first since Herman Cain dropped out of the race—and with less than two months to go before the Iowa caucuses, it's the last chance for every candidate to make a first impression. Here's what to watch for: Will the Cain circus die down? Cain's sexual harassment allegations are certain to come up, and if he can't move the conversation away from them, he's in big trouble. Will his rivals attack him directly? Or will they let him "bleed slowly as they avert their eyes." Will Newt Gingrich finally get to the top of the polls? The former House speaker has been rising in the polls, but he'll likely need a big night to crack the top three. Will Mitt Romney's armor survive the "Not-Mitt" movement? It's no secret that Romney is the front-runner, but this "Anybody-but-Mitt" movement has emerged, led by Jon Huntsman Jr., and it's time for Romney's rivals to step up and take on the " Transformers-style" movement, writes David A. – A&E has suspended Duck Dynasty patriarch Phil Robertson over anti-gay comments he made in a GQ interview. In the interview, he said that homosexuality is a sin that should not be treated as a "choice." He also said that women are "more desirable than a man's anus." In a statement, A&E called the comments "some of the vilest and most extreme statements uttered by a member of our family" and said it was canceling the show while it investigates the matter. "We are extremely disappointed to have read Phil Robertson's comments in the magazine, which are based on his own personal beliefs and are not in line with the values of the network," it said. Robertson has been suspended from the show while the controversy plays out. GQ writer Tim Goodman, who interviewed Robertson in Louisiana, tweeted that he was "appalled and disappointed" by the suspension. "A&E should not punish a man for saying what is indefensible," he wrote. "They should suspend the show until they understand the full context of Phil Robertson's statements and actions." A&E has not commented publicly on the suspension, but TMZ reports that the network is working on a second season of Duck Dynasty. In the GQ interview

– Eight critically endangered black rhinos are dead in Kenya after wildlife workers moved them from the capital to a new national park, the government said Friday, calling the toll "unprecedented" in more than a decade of such transfers. Preliminary investigations point to salt poisoning as the rhinos tried to adapt to saltier water in their new home, the Kenyan Ministry of Tourism and Wildlife said in a statement, per the AP. It suspended the ongoing move of other rhinos and said the surviving ones were being closely monitored. "This kind of mortality rate is unprecedented in Kenya Wildlife Service operations," the ministry said. "A total of 14 rhinos had been planned to be translocated. It was the first time since the 1990s that black rhinos had been moved to Tsavo East, which originally had a population of nearly 2,000, but now has between 10 and 20. We have to say it openly when it happens, not a week later or a month later." Save the Rhino estimates there are fewer than 5,500 black rhinos in the world, all of them in Africa, while Kenya's black rhino population stands at 750, according to the World Wide Fund for Nature. Losing the rhinos was "a complete disaster," the prominent Kenyan conservationist Paula Ka

– A North Korean soldier says he shot and killed his platoon and squad chiefs before defecting across the DMZ today, South Korean military officials say. South Korean troops at the border heard gunshots and escorted the soldier to a guard post, where he is being interrogated, the BBC reports. It's believed to be the first defection along the DMZ since 2010. The last North Korean soldier to defect was in 2010, the New York Times reports. Analysts say there is no indication the defection indicates instability in the North. "Those who are stationed in the border area, around the DMZ and especially right on the DMZ, are those who are considered to be loyal to the regime," says Daniel Pinkston of the International Crisis Group in Seoul. "They've been screened and they do not put people there who would be considered disloyal."

– If you're looking for a little extra cash this summer, there's a good chance you'll find it in California's gold country, KPIX 5 reports. That's because recent heavy rains have caused runoff that's shaking the hills and soil so much that it's now possible to find gold. "It's going to bring up new areas that I never got to," says "Miner Gary" Thomas. "It's going to shake the gold from these hills, and it could provide a 'Eureka' moment for those inclined to come up here and look for it." Thomas says he usually finds at least a little gold on his property near Jamestown in Tuolumne County, but this year, there's so much more runoff that it could provide a "Eureka" moment for those inclined to come up here and look for it. "That's hard to do," he says. "Eureka!" But not as hard this year, now that Mother Nature has shaken up the motherlode, because the huge water releases from the Oroville Dam spillway could reveal some new pockets of gold. – A North Carolina couple is suing the producers of HGTV's Love It or List It, claiming the hit show turned their dream home into a nightmare, the Raleigh News & Observer reports. Deena Murphy and Timothy Sullivan say they agreed to participate in the hit show, in which homeowners are renovated while they consider moving into a new home. According to Today, the couple gave the production company $140,000 for the renovations, but only about $85,000 of that went to the contractor. They say the rest was used "for the production of its series." They also say the show never used a licensed architect, never showed houses for sale in North Carolina, and never had work done on the house that was actually for sale by a real estate broker. According to the lawsuit, the work done on the house was "disastrous," leaving it with "low-grade industrial carpeting, unpainted surfaces, and windows painted shut." vermin entered the house, and ducts were left open. The lawsuit claims the production company and the contractor, Aaron Fitz Construction, are "actors or television personalities playing a role for the camera," not people who "played more than a casual role in the actual renovation process." Big Coat TV and Fitz Construction are both named as defendants in the lawsuit.

– One of two Wisconsin girls accused in the 2014 "Slender Man" stabbing of a classmate will plead not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect next week, the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel reports. Anissa Weier's attorney filed a plea of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect this week. Morgan Geyser already entered a plea of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect last month. Weier's attorney says Weier now wants to change her not guilty plea to the insanity plea. A hearing is set for Sept. 9. Weier and Geyser, both 14, are accused of stabbing their classmate Payton Leutner 19 times and leaving her for dead in a Waukesha park in an attempt to please the fictional Internet character Slender Man. Both girls are charged as adults with attempted first-degree intentional homicide. Geyser has been diagnosed with early onset schizophrenia and is currently in a state mental hospital. Weier remains in a juvenile detention center. Her trial hasn't yet been set. (The girls' attorneys had been trying to move them into juvenile court.)

– A 90-year-old California man has been charged with murder after his stepdaughter's Fitbit data suggested she may have killed herself, ABC News reports. Karen Navarra, 67, was found dead in her San Jose home on Sept. 13 with a gaping wound to her neck, a deep laceration on her head, and a kitchen knife in her hand. A medical examiner determined she couldn't have caused all the wounds herself, and police believed the scene was staged to appear as a suicide. Police spoke to Navarra's stepfather, Anthony Aiello, who said he last saw her Sept. 8 when he brought pizza to her home. Aiello told police when he was later outside his house, he heard a car honk and saw Navarra drive by waving with a second person in the passenger seat, the document said. Police recovered surveillance video from near Aiello's home and determined Navarra never drove by that day, according to police. The Fitbit Alta HR on her left wrist showed a significant spike in her heart rate Sept. 8 at 3:20pm, followed by a rapid slowing, the document said. The Fitbit stopped registering heart rate data that day at 3:28pm. Police also checked surveillance video near Navarra's home and

– A male University of Chicago student who says he was falsely accused of sexual assault by two women is suing the school, the Chicago Maroon reports. According to a lawsuit filed last week, the student, identified only as John Doe, met Jane Roe and Jane Roe in 2013 through a Facebook page for accepted students. The lawsuit states the two women had consensual relationships with John Doe, but Jane Roe started publicly accusing him of sexual assault in 2016. The lawsuit states John Doe was denied a Title IX complaint against Jane Doe for harassment and retaliation and was subjected to a "fundamentally unfair, arbitrary, and capricious disciplinary procedure that violates both Title IX and UC's policies and/or procedures related to allegations of sexual misconduct." The lawsuit states Roe wrote a Tumblr blog post in 2014 in which she falsely accused John Doe of sexual misconduct and advised members of UC's community that he was a sexual predator, Jezebel reports. The lawsuit states Roe also "falsely and maliciously advised members of UC's community that John Doe was a sexual predator." The male student is seeking $175,000 in damages against the university. The federal government is investigating the University of Chicago for allegedly violating Title IX by not investigating sexual assault claims based on gender.

– Senior Obama adviser David Plouffe today called Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich's criticism of the president's response to the Trayvon Martin shooting "reprehensible" and "hard to stomach," reports CNN. "I think those comments were really hard to stomach, really, and I guess trying to appeal to people's worst instincts," he said. "I don't think there's very many people in America that would share that reaction," he added. "You know, this Republican primary at some points has been more of a circus show and a clown show." Elsewhere on your Sunday dial, as per Politico: Plouffe on ObamaCare: "We are confident it will be upheld." He declined to say whether Obama would fight a gay marriage plank in the Democratic Party's platform. "We don’t even have a platform committee. We are going to work through the platform process." Gingrich on Obama's Trayvon comment: "Is the president suggesting if it had been a white who had been shot, that would be OK because it wouldn't look like him? That's just nonsense. I mean dividing this country up, it is a tragedy this young man was shot." Santorum on Obama's response: "The

– A body believed to be that of missing Florida woman Savannah Gold was found in a pond Saturday night, Action News Jax reports. According to the Florida Times-Union, the 28-year-old's co-worker at Bonefish Grill, 28-year-old Lee Rodarte, was arrested Saturday night and charged with murder and tampering with evidence. Police say Gold got into Rodarte's car in the restaurant's parking lot Wednesday evening and had a fight with him. Rodarte allegedly slashed the tire of Gold's car and drove off. He returned to his car and was seen on surveillance video looking inside Gold's car. Gold was never seen leaving the car. Police say Rodarte admitted to killing Gold and dumping her body in the pond at the end of Club Duclay Road.

– Chris Brown and Rihanna have been spending a lot of time together lately, sources tell the New York Post, but they’re not exactly getting along. “Rihanna and Chris Brown are seeing a lot of each other in private,” says one. “They’re very close in private.” They’ve been spotted at the same clubs twice in the past two weeks, but have kept their distance. Meanwhile, Rihanna’s latest ad campaign, featuring a see-through shot of her in a bra and skirt, is dominating Times Square, the Daily Mail reports.

– "It's a Super Bowl tradition to speculate about the performers for the Pepsi Halftime Show," the NFL says in a statement to Entertainment Tonight. "We are continuing to work with Pepsi on our plans, but do not have any announcements to make on what will be another epic show." Multiple sources tell Variety that Maroon 5 will be the halftime performer at Super Bowl LIII on Feb. 3 in Atlanta. "It's a dream come true for Adam Levine and his six bandmates," a source tells Us Weekly. "The offer has been extended and they've pretty much accepted." Maroon 5, made up of Levine, Jesse Carmichael, James Valentine, PJ Morton, Matt Flynn, Sam Farrar, and Mickey Madden, is currently on their Red Pill Blues Tour, which kicks off in Las Vegas on Feb. 19. Levine has said in the past that he and his bandmates "very actively want to play the Super Bowl."

– Authorities say a man who held up a Denver bank got a cab ride to and from the robbery, the AP reports. The Denver Post reports the FBI is asking for the public's help to find the suspect. Authorities say the man took a cab to the bank, asked the driver to idle while he went inside, and then had the cabbie drive him to Denver International Airport. Officials say it's unknown if the suspect actually boarded a plane after going to the airport. Video from inside the cab clearly shows the man's face, and pictures taken in the Public Service Credit Union show the man wearing what appears to be a white dust mask while inside the bank, where he threatened a teller with a small handgun.

– Rome's official Christmas tree has been nicknamed "Spelacchio, or Mangy" after the 72-foot Norway spruce began to lose its needles. The New York Times reports the tree arrived in Rome early this month from the Trentino region, and what with transport expenses and decorations, the 70-foot fir is estimated to have cost Italian taxpayers $57,000. It's not clear what has ailed it. Maybe Spelacchio was unsettled by the trip; perhaps it was ill on departure. By way of explanation, tree historian Antimo Palumbo, a tree historian who was standing by Spelacchio's side on Friday morning, pointed at the concrete all over its roots. "You see that?" he told me. "They decided to pour the concrete to keep it steady, but that killed it instead." There isn't enough time, money, or political will to replace the tree, and so Spelacchio the Mangy will stay in Piazza Venezia through the holidays, and for many locals it has already become a metaphor for what's wrong with the city, and the country. Traffic in Rome is chronically congested, public transport is inefficient, trash collection is slow, and sporadic. Early hopes about Virginia Raggi, who was elected

– The third and final day of Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court confirmation hearing has wrapped up, with the judge getting pressed on a wide range of topics. Here's a look at some of the highlights, via the AP, the Washington Post, the New York Times, and the Los Angeles Times: On Roe v. Wade: "The court has never ruled that Roe v. Wade is settled law," Kavanaugh said, per the Times. "It has never ruled that a president has the power to decide a case in the midst of a presidential campaign." But he added that courts are "the final word" on such matters. Gay rights: Kavanaugh declined to say whether the Supreme Court's ruling legalizing same-sex marriage was correctly decided, the New York Times reports. He did, however, say that gay people "cannot be treated as social outcasts or as inferior in dignity and worth." Mueller: "I have no knowledge of or have knowledge of any improper contact" between President Trump and Russia, Kavanaugh said when pressed by Sen. Kamala Harris of California. He did, however, say he has not been briefed on Robert Mueller's investigation. Abortion: "I believe Roe v. Wade is settled law," Kavanaugh said when pressed by Sen.

– The brouhaha over Family Guy's decision to air an image of the prophet Muhammad has turned into a real-life soap opera, according to the New York Daily News. The Daily News reports that Fox ordered 20 episodes of the show to be pulled after the network threatened to ban an upcoming episode over the image. According to the Hollywood Reporter, the decision to pull the episodes was made by Fox Animation, the show's parent company. The episode in question, titled "The Battle for Muhammad," was supposed to air on Sept. 14. But Fox ordered the episodes to be pulled after it was discovered that they were being produced by Warner Bros., which produces Family Guy. The decision to pull the episodes was made by Warner Bros., not Family Guy’s parent company, according to the Reporter. The episode in question, which was supposed to air Sept. 14, was produced by Warner Bros., which produces Family Guy.

– President Obama's campaign and the Democratic National Committee raised $43 million in the third quarter, reports the New York Times, a hefty sum that puts them on pace to easily top the $150 million raised by the GOP and the DNC in the entire election cycle. But the president's financial strength doesn't guarantee victory, notes the Los Angeles Times. Polls show that voters are more likely to vote for an unnamed Republican candidate than for Obama in 2012. Obama is still relying heavily on big donors, including former Goldman Sachs executive Jon Corzine and Dreamworks Animation chief executive Jeffrey Katzenberg, who have raised at least $500,000 for the president. At least 41 people have raised at least half a million dollars for the president, compared to 27 in Obama's first report. The president regularly brings in more than $1 million in a single evening of fundraising, as supporters donate the legal maximum of $35,800 to his campaign and the Democratic party for the chance to have dinner and take a picture with the president. At least 40% of all the money raised by the Obama campaign and the Democratic National Committee last quarter came from those giving in increments of $200 or less. "They are still doing well with small donors," said a Brookings Institution director of governance studies.

– A woman was killed and at least five others were injured Saturday when a 100-foot-tall eucalyptus tree uprooted and fell on a wedding party in a California park, the Los Angeles Times reports. According to the Whittier Daily News, the wedding party was taking pictures under the tree at Penn Park when it suddenly fell. "It was supposed to be one of the most exciting days of their lives," the mayor of Whittier says. "Instead, it turned into what it turned into." A 4-year-old girl was hospitalized in critical condition. The other five injured people suffered minor to moderate injuries and were taken to a hospital for treatment. A search dog was brought in to look for more victims who could still be trapped under the tree. "Fortunately, there weren't more people injured by the tree collapse," a Los Angeles County Fire Department deputy chief says. "It could have been a lot worse." The wedding party was taken to a senior center where mental health counselors were available to them, NBC Los Angeles reports. It's not clear what caused the tree to fall. An arborist is expected to inspect the scene Sunday or Monday.

– Authorities on Wednesday were searching for an inmate they believe has made his second escape from a maximum-security South Carolina prison. Officers began searching just before 2pm Wednesday for Jimmy Causey, an inmate at Lieber Correctional Institution, about 90 miles southeast of Columbia, according to Sommer Sharpe, spokeswoman for the Department of Corrections. No other details have been released, the AP reports. Causey, 46, has now escaped from two different prisons in a dozen years. He and another inmate, convicted murderer Johnny Brewer, escaped Broad River Correctional Institution in Columbia in 2005 by hiding in a trash truck. The pair eluded authorities for three days before being apprehended at a motel along busy Interstate 95, not far from the prison from which Causey escaped on Wednesday. A pizza delivery driver told the AP at the time she tipped off authorities when she recognized a customer as one of the two men being sought by authorities. Both men were returned to prison. Brewer was found two years later, hanging from a bed sheet in his cell. Grilled by state lawmakers about how the escape happened, then-prisons director Jon Ozmint blamed budget cutbacks that had forced his department to cut 800 security positions, leaving some areas like the trash compactor and loading dock unmonitored by officers. The director also said

– Lois Lerner, the IRS official at the center of the agency's Tea Party mess, has been placed on administrative leave, reports the Hill. Lerner, who heads the IRS division that oversees tax-exempt groups, first revealed the extra scrutiny conservative groups received almost two weeks ago, when she asked a lawyer at an American Bar Association conference whether the IRS had targeted conservative groups. Lerner has been under fire from lawmakers from both parties for her role in the scandal, and on Wednesday, she invoked her Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination at a House Oversight hearing. She will still be paid while on leave, reports the Washington Post. New IRS chief Danny Werfel had asked her to resign, but she refused. "Not only is she the person who was in charge of the group that wrongly targeted conservatives, she dishonestly testified that she didn’t know about the targeting until 2012, when the inspector general found she knew as early as 2011," writes Matthew Yglesias at Slate. "She’s the person who told a conference call of reporters, 'I’m not that good at math,' even though she’s a manager in an agency that’s at bottom all about math."

– Bob Woodward's new book, The Choice, takes a behind-the-scenes look at the Clintons, including the first lady's imaginary conversations with dead people. In the Chicago Sun-Times, Woodward writes that Hillary Clinton "virtually moved into the White House" to help write her book, It Takes a Village and Other Lessons Children Teach Us, and had imaginary chats with dead people including Eleanor Roosevelt, Mahatma Gandhi, and Jean Houston, co-director of the Foundation for Mind Research. "Most people in the White House did not know about Hillary's sessions with Houston," Woodward writes. "To some of the few who did, the meetings could trigger politically damaging comparisons to Nancy Reagan's use of astrology." Clinton's spokeswoman, Lisa Caputo, says the first lady's interest in Houston is no secret, CNN reports. Clinton herself wrote about the imaginary conversations in her June 10 column. "She usually responds by telling me to buck up, or at least to grow skin as thick as a rhinoceros," she wrote.

– Doctors at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine say they've performed the world's first total penis and scrotum transplant on a US serviceman who was severely injured by an IED blast in Afghanistan several years ago. The unnamed man, whose identity has not been released, is recovering well and is expected to regain both urinary and sexual function, reports USA Today. The 14-hour procedure, which involved a large skin graft covering part of the sergeant's abdomen, was the most extensive yet, involving more tissue than has been previously transplanted. In addition to a large skin graft covering part of the sergeant's abdomen, penis and scrotum, surgeons connected three arteries, four veins, and two nerves to provide blood flow and sensation to the donated tissue. The patient did not receive testicles from his donor to avoid the ethical issues that might ensue if he later had children, says Damon Cooney, another transplant team member. The donor was not identified, nor was his cause of death, but in a statement, his family praised the sergeant's service to his country and noted the donor family includes a number of veterans. "We are so thankful to say that our loved one would be proud and honored to know he provided such a special gift to you," said

– Melquan Kwame Robinson's parents are "upset over the fact of how could this happen," a family friend tells the Augusta Chronicle. The 12-year-old Georgia boy was electrocuted at a youth football practice Monday night when he touched a fence that had been electrified by a live wire. Three other people were injured in the incident, including a child who tried to pull Melquan from the fence. "The friends, the way they responded, what motivates a young boy that young to jump into action and help their friend out," the friend tells the Chronicle. "Those are the two young boys that are in the hospital right now because they were trying to help out a friend." Melquan's parents are also grieving the loss of their firstborn and one of three children, the family friend says. "You can play the what ifs in many different scenarios and it will never get any better," he says. "The fact that this situation happened with so many kids out here, it's heartbreaking." Melquan was a member of the Trinity Elite Titans football team, which posted a statement on Facebook: "Good morning everyone, this is a sad moment for our Trinity Elite Titans family......we are still in disbelief. We are sending our prayers

– The first gay marriages took place in Hawaii just after midnight, as the state's new same-sex marriage law took effect. Six couples got married shortly after midnight, reports the AP, and dozens more are expected to tie the knot before the end of the day. The first licenses will be issued to same-sex couples at the State Department of Health's marriage bureau, which will be open from 9am to 5pm, reports the Honolulu Star-Advertiser. Couples can register for a license online, then be verified by a license agent throughout the state. Hawaii already has a thriving tourism industry, so the state hopes the new law will spur more visits by same-sex couples, who "will be attracted to Hawaii for the same reasons that opposite-sex couples are attracted to Hawaii," an economist tells NPR.

– Nasdaq halted trading in all its stocks for three hours this afternoon due to a massive technical glitch, reports MarketWatch. The New York Stock Exchange also stopped trading in Nasdaq-listed securities at the request of Nasdaq, notes the Wall Street Journal. Nasdaq officials are still trying to figure out what happened and when trading will resume.

– It's that time of year again: time to dig out your snow shovels and get back to work. If you're like most of us, you've probably suffered some sort of back injury while doing so, and now a new study suggests you might want to think about getting a physiotherapist to come to your aid. The study, published in the journal Physical Review Letters, looked at the effects of exercise on the musculoskeletal system, including the back, neck, and shoulder, and found that those who used a physiotherapist's advice to rehabilitate their backs after snow shoveling fared better than those who used a non- physiotherapist's advice, reports the Telegraph. The findings: Those who used a physiotherapist's advice to rehabilitate their backs fared better than those who used a non- physiotherapist's advice, even after controlling for a number of factors, including age, previous injuries, and level of snow shoveling experience. The study also found that those who used a physiotherapist's advice to rehabilitate their backs fared better than those who used a non- physiotherapist's advice, even after controlling for a number of factors, including age, previous injuries, and level of snow shoveling experience. But don't think this means you need to get a physiotherapist

– Idina Menzel and Taye Diggs are splitting up after a 10-year marriage, People reports. "Idina Menzel and Taye Diggs have jointly decided to separate at this time," a rep for Menzel tells Us. "Their primary focus and concern is for their son. We ask that you respect their privacy during this time." Diggs and Menzel, both 42, met while costarring in the original Broadway production of Rent in 1995 and later reprised their roles in the 2005 film adaptation. They married in 2003 and had a son, Walker, in 2009.

– For centuries, scholars have wondered whether the site where Jesus is believed to have been buried was actually moved or destroyed. Now, after a major restoration at Jerusalem's Church of the Holy Sepulchre last year, scientists say they've dated the site to the AD 325 period when the Romans were said to have discovered it, National Geographic reports. "Scientists and archaeologists are very excited about this because, what it does is, it corroborates our historical accounts," says National Geographic archaeology writer Kristin Romey, who was on the site during the nine-month restoration project. "There is so much information in the data that was collected by the restorers during the conservation project," says an archaeologist. "There are many, many stories still to be told." The tomb, known as the Holy Edicule, was opened for the first time in centuries in October 2016. It's the size of a coat closet and was open for just 60 hours while restoration work was carried out. To date, the earliest architectural evidence found in and around the tomb complex dated to the Crusader period, making it no older than 1,000 years. While it is archaeologically impossible to say that the tomb is the burial site of an individual Jew known as Jesus of Nazareth, who according to

– A pair of Picassos owned by former casino mogul Steve Wynn have been pulled from a Christie's auction after being damaged "during the final stages of preparation," the auction house says. The 1943 self-portrait Le Marin, estimated at $70 million, was one of three Wynn owned by Christie's for an estimated $135 million this week, Bloomberg reports. On Monday, Picasso's 1964 portrait of a woman with a cat, Femme au chat assise dans un fauteuil, was also pulled from the auction by mutual agreement with the seller. Wynn, who suffers from a disease that affects his peripheral vision, accidentally struck his Picasso "Le Reve" with his right elbow in 2006 while showing it to friends in his Las Vegas office. The painting had been worth $139 million before that, according to Wynn's lawsuit against the insurer, Lloyd's of London. A restorer said the repaired painting was worth $85 million, according to the lawsuit. Hedge fund titan Steve Cohen bought it from Wynn in 2013 for $155 million. (Wynn resigned as CEO of Wynn Resorts in February amid sexual misconduct allegations.)

– Sierra Nevada Brewing Co. is hoping to raise $10 million for wildfire relief in Butte County, Calif., with the release of a limited-edition beer. Resilience Butte County Proud IPA will be available Dec. 20 from more than 1,400 breweries across the US and will be donated 100% to the Sierra Nevada Camp Fire Relief Fund, the company says in a press release. "We committed to brewing the beer and donating 100% of the sales to the Sierra Nevada Camp Fire Relief Fund, aimed at long-term community rebuilding support," says brewer Luke Dickinson. "And thank you to every single customer who is helping us rebuild our Butte County community—one pint at a time." The fire destroyed more than 13,000 homes and killed at least 85 people in November, per the Los Angeles Times. (Last month, a cider house in New York's Central Park held a benefit for victims of the wildfires.)

– If you're looking for a new way to lose weight, a new study suggests you might want to start playing Tetris. Researchers asked 71 car crash victims waiting for treatment at one hospital to briefly recall a traumatic incident, then gave half of them a written activity to do while the other half played the game, reports the New York Times. They found that those who played the game while waiting for treatment were less likely to be diagnosed with PTSD than those who played the game while they were still in the hospital. The study, published in the journal JAMA Internal Medicine, didn't examine why the Tetris-playing group was less likely to have PTSD than the other group, but lead researcher Dr. Supat Thammasitboon of the University of Sydney says it's possible the game played while they were in the hospital may have helped them deal with the stress of being in a car accident. "It's possible that the stress of being in a car accident may have helped them to deal with the PTSD that they were dealing with at the time," he says. "It's also possible that playing Tetris while in the hospital may have helped them to deal with the PTSD that they were not dealing with at the time." (A new study suggests that

– A former associate of Paul Manafort has become the second person to plead guilty in Robert Mueller's investigation. Sam Patten, 47, pleaded guilty Friday to failing to register as a foreign agent for lobbying on behalf of a Ukrainian political party, Bloomberg reports. Patten, a former State Department official who headed the Moscow office of the International Republican Institute in the early 2000s, reportedly worked with Manafort and on Ukrainian campaigns, and reportedly worked on microtargeting operations with Cambridge Analytica. Patten worked with Manafort and on Ukrainian campaigns, and reportedly worked on microtargeting operations with Cambridge Analytica. Patten appeared in federal court in Washington, DC, Friday. Patten's plea agreement also included the suggestion that the Trump Inaugural Committee improperly accepted funds from a foreigner. Patten admitted that he illegally helped a Ukrainian oligarch buy a ticket to Trump's swearing-in through a straw-man donor, though as part of his cooperation agreement he wasn't charged. In addition to working with Manafort and on Ukrainian campaigns, Patten worked with a "prominent" Ukrainian oligarch who isn't named in court papers and his Opposition Bloc political party with lobbying and consulting services, according to the criminal information. – South Korean President Park Geun-hye is in the midst of a political scandal that could result in her impeachment, and one item in her office is raising eyebrows: Viagra. Park's office has confirmed that it bought about 360 erectile dysfunction pills and a generic version of the drug in December to treat altitude sickness on official trips to Ethiopia, Uganda, and Kenya, where capitals are thousands of feet above sea level, the Guardian reports. South Korean doctors sometimes prescribe Viagra-style drugs to climbers because they are believed to be effective in preventing altitude sickness. The revelation comes as Park grapples with a massive political scandal. The president is now bracing for an impeachment push by opposition parties and some members of her own Saenuri party amid allegations that she let a secretive confidante manipulate government affairs and amass an illicit fortune, a scandal critics say undermines the country's democracy. On Wednesday South Korean prosecutors raided offices of the Samsung Group and the state pension fund as the electronics giant was dragged further into the scandal engulfing Park. While the report has created a frenzy on the internet, Park's office said the pills were bought to potentially treat altitude sickness for presidential aides and employees on Park's May trips to Ethiopia, Uganda, and Kenya, whose capitals are

– If searchers are indeed getting pings from the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, they're running out of time. Search chief Angus Houston said today that equipment on board the Australian ship Ocean Shield has been unable to locate the faint signals, which are consistent with signals from aircraft black boxes, since they were picked up on Saturday and Sunday, reports CBS News. "It's literally crawling at the bottom of the ocean, so it's going to take a long, long time," Houston said. "There's still a little bit of doubt there, but I'm a lot more optimistic than I was one week ago." If the signals are indeed from the plane, they would have been picked up by the Ocean Shield's towed pinger locator, which is designed to detect signals up to a mile deep in the ocean. Houston said it would be a "logistical nightmare" if the signals hadn't been detected, reports the BBC. If the signals are indeed from the plane, they would have been picked up by the Ocean Shield's ping detector, which is designed to detect signals up to a mile deep, reports the New York Times. – Kate Downing has been on the city council of Palo Alto, Calif., for five years. That's a long time in politics in the San Francisco Bay Area, so when she penned a letter to the mayor and city council explaining that she and her family were moving to Santa Cruz "because we cannot see a way to stay in Palo Alto and raise a family here," she probably didn't expect it to get picked up by the media. But that's exactly what happened, reports the San Jose Mercury News, with Downing's letter getting picked up by the Palo Alto Weekly, the San Francisco Chronicle, and other outlets. "I struggle to think what Palo Alto will become and what it will represent when young families have no hope of ever putting down roots here," she writes. "The loudest voices in the community feel that the desire to create more affordable housing is spoiled entitlement. Until renters, younger people, and people of more modest means organize, this problem will continue throughout the Bay Area." (Click to read about another Bay Area city that's trying to do something about its housing crisis.)

– The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have a new bundle of joy, but they're keeping the name of the puppy a secret, the Telegraph reports. "He is a private pet and they do not want his name to be made public although the couple are happy to confirm that they do, indeed, have a new dog," says a St. James's Palace spokesman. The 3-month-old male cocker spaniel is the son of Kate's mother's litter. "William and Catherine fell in love with the pup instantly and it wasn't long before they decided to keep him," a palace aide tells US Weekly. "He's now part of the royal fold!" The couple's first dog is Prince William's black labrador, Widgeon, who died two years ago. Spaniels are one of the oldest known breeds of dogs, and the queen owns three corgis. Click for more on the royal pooch.

– If you're going to let your phone do the talking in the movie theater, don't do it while you're in an AMC theater. That's the message from the theater chain after its CEO floated the idea of allowing moviegoers to text during movies this week, USA Today reports. "We have heard loud and clear this is a concept our audience does not want," AMC Theatres CEO Adam Aron said in a statement Friday. "NO TEXTING AT AMC. Won't happen. You spoke. We listened. Quickly, that idea has been sent to the cutting room floor." In a Wednesday interview with Variety, Aron said his company was considering allowing texting in some auditoriums to draw in millennials. "When you tell a 22-year-old to turn off the phone, don't ruin the movie, they hear please cut off your left arm above the elbow," he said. "You can't tell a 22-year-old to turn off their cellphone. That's not how they live." The reaction on social media was swift, with many people threatening to take their business elsewhere if the plan went through. "So, I guess I won't be seeing movies at AMC theaters," one person tweeted. "AMC CEO suggests

– OJ Simpson will be released on parole in October after serving nine years for armed robbery and kidnapping, the Nevada Board of Parole decided Thursday. The 4-0 vote came after Simpson, 70, apologized for his role in the 2007 incident and said he had "lived a conflict-free life" in prison, CNN reports. "I've done my time," Simpson said. "I've done it as well and as respectfully as I think anyone can." Simpson was acquitted of murder in 1995 for the deaths of ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald Goldman. At the hearing, Simpson said he had taken two "Alternative to Violence" classes and that he plans to move to Florida. "I've spent nine years making no excuses about anything," he said. "I am sorry that things turned out the way they did. I had no intent to commit a crime." Simpson was sentenced to nine to 33 years in prison for his role in the armed robbery and kidnapping of two sports memorabilia dealers in a Las Vegas hotel room. One of the two memorabilia dealers Simpson was convicted of robbing testified in favor of his release, saying he has forgiven Simpson. Tom Riccio, the man who arranged the robbery, told CNN that Simpson "should wish he didn't

– Scott Baio says the wife of Red Hot Chili Peppers drummer Chad Smith attacked him at an event Saturday because he's a Donald Trump supporter, People reports. According to TMZ, Baio was at an event with his daughter at an elementary school in Thousand Oaks, Calif., when Nancy Mack, wife of the Chili Peppers drummer, confronted him and started yelling at him. Baio says he asked Mack to calm down, but she kept yelling at him, saying, "Grab 'em by the pu**y." Baio says he asked her to stop, but she kept yelling at him. Sources say Mack was mimicking how Trump hugs women and didn't actually hurt Baio. The Ventura County Sheriff's Department is investigating the incident. Mack is listed as a battery suspect.

– More former Ohio State wrestlers are accusing Rep. Jim Jordan of covering up sexual abuse by a team doctor more than 20 years ago, NBC News reports. "I participated with Jimmy and the other wrestlers in locker-room talk about Strauss. We all did," Shawn Dailey says. "It was very common knowledge in the locker room that if you went to Dr. Strauss for anything, you would have to pull your pants down." Dailey, 43, says he was groped half a dozen times by Strauss in the mid-1990s, when Jordan was the assistant wrestling coach. He says he was too embarrassed to report the abuse directly to Jordan at the time, but he says Jordan took part in conversations where Strauss' abuse of many other team members came up. "Jimmy said something to the extent of, 'If he tried that with me, I would kill him,'" Dailey says. "What happened drove me out of the sport. So I was surprised to hear Jim say that he knew nothing about it." Another former wrestler, Mark Coleman, tells the Wall Street Journal that Jordan was aware of the abuse and had not taken action. – A quick-thinking 911 dispatcher in Johnston County, NC, may have saved a woman's life after she called 911 to say she was locked in the trunk of a moving car. Jason Barbour, director of the Johnston County Emergency 911 Communications Center, tells ABC News that the 29-year-old woman called around 4am on Jan. 14. "She was crying and very upset, so it was hard to understand her at first, but [Medlin] finally heard her say she was locked in a trunk of a car," Barbour says. He says Medlin tried to call the woman, but the call was disconnected. Then, "she started texting back and told us that she needed help and that she believed she was in a red Mustang headed towards Fayetteville," Barbour says. According to WRAL, the woman provided the make and color of the car and said she believed she was on her way to Fayetteville. The woman's boyfriend, 32-year-old Nicholas Mattevi, was arrested and charged with false imprisonment, ABC reports. Barbour says the woman may not have been found if it wasn't for Medlin's quick thinking. "He really stood by our motto, 'Failure is not an option,'" Barbour tells WRAL. (

– If you've got a MasterCard or Visa, there's a good chance you'll soon be asked to dip it in a reader instead of swiping it at a store checkout. That's because Thursday is the deadline for retailers to update their payment terminals to accept the new "chip-enabled" cards, which MasterCard and Visa are rolling out in the US later this year, the Wall Street Journal reports. The change, which Visa and MasterCard say will make the US the most secure country in the world for credit and debit cards, is meant to reduce fraud, which has more than doubled in the US over the past 15 years. But while the new cards are more secure than their magnetic-strip counterparts, they're also more expensive to use, taking between five and 10 seconds to process compared to three to five seconds with the magnetic-strip system, Tech Times reports. Some retailers, including RadioShack and 7-Eleven, say they've already upgraded their payment terminals to accept the new cards, but banks—not retailers—are the ones who will be responsible for fraudulent transactions if they don't update their equipment. (Visa says counterfeit credit and debit cards make up two-thirds of all fraud reported in the US.)

– Pippi Longstocking actress Tami Erin was arrested Saturday afternoon for felony hit and run and drunk driving, TMZ reports. Erin, who played the red-headed girl in the 1988 movie, allegedly hit three cars and took off. At least one person was taken to the hospital. One source says Erin was "totally out of control ... just out of it." She refused a blood alcohol test and her bail was set at $100K. Meanwhile, TMZ reports that Columbia Pictures, the studio behind the original movie, got wind that multiple websites were using images from the movie to promote a sex tape. Columbia’s lawyers sent out an email warning the websites to take down the images or face a lawsuit. One of the XXX sites responded by adding a disclaimer on its home page saying the sex tape is not sponsored, endorsed, or affiliated with the studio. It’s not clear how Columbia feels about the compromise.

– When a freshman died after a booze-filled initiation ritual at California Polytechnic State University in 2010, the school banned all fraternities from recruiting new members for a year. But the ban was overturned this year after student leaders staged a three-year campaign against the ban, Bloomberg reports. Now, the Interfraternity Conference, a trade group for 75 national fraternities, is fighting against delaying recruitment by a semester or a year. "These organizations were putting our freshmen at risk," said Shirley Tilghman, former president of Princeton, which banned fraternity recruiting of freshmen in 2012. "There is so much vulnerability in that first week, that first month as a freshman on a college campus—of feeling lost. It leads to all kinds of decisions that you would not make if you had a little more time to find your way." Of 60 fraternity-related deaths nationwide since 2005, 40% were of freshmen, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Only 80 of about 800 US campuses with fraternities defer recruiting, according to the conference. Fraternity membership surged to 327,260 in 2011 from 253,148 in 2005. National fraternities and affiliated foundations generated $185 million in student dues and other revenue in 2010-2011, up 24% from 2005-2006, tax records show.
