– As Hurricane Irene bears down on the East Coast, states of emergency have been declared in Virginia, Maryland, and Washington, DC, where Sunday's dedication of the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial has been postponed, the Washington Post reports. “I’m disappointed and hurt, really,” says the chief executive of the memorial project. “But the memorial is going to be there forever.” Irene is expected to hit North Carolina tonight and hit New Jersey tomorrow. The worst of the storm is expected to hit Virginia, Maryland, and the District tomorrow night and into Sunday morning. Meanwhile, Irene weakened slightly to a Category 2 storm as it approached the East Coast, where a hurricane warning was also extended to New Jersey. If the hurricane stays on track, the worst of Irene will arrive in Virginia, Maryland, and the District later Saturday and into Sunday morning. Late-summer vacationers evacuated Atlantic coast beaches, which are expected to be hit hardest before the storm wallops New England. In the Washington region, there were warnings that people should be prepared for power outages as toppling trees take down electrical lines. Road crews were on alert to clear fallen trees and other wind-driven debris from highways. More than 2,000 sandbags were being placed at Metro stations where water tends to come

– Scientists say they've figured out a way to turn used coffee grounds into alcohol, a development that could change the way hard liquor is consumed in the US. Microbrewers already flavor their beers with coffee, and scientists collected coffee grounds from a Portuguese roasting company and heated the powder in water for 45 minutes, separated out the liquid, and added sugar. Next, they mixed in yeast cells, let the concoction ferment, and concentrated the sample to get a higher alcohol content, reports Science. To evaluate the product, eight trained taste testers were brought in and rated the intensity of different smells and flavors in the alcohol. The judges described the drink as smelling like coffee and tasting bitter and pungent. Researchers noted that the taste could be improved with age and concluded that the quality was good enough for consumption. Don't count on the caffeine to keep you awake, however; most of it disappears in the brewing process.

– The Vatican says Pope Francis was "shocked and profoundly saddened" by a murderous attack at a home for the elderly in southern Yemen that killed 16 people, including four nuns. The Vatican secretary of state said in a condolence message on Saturday that the pontiff "prays that this pointless slaughter will awaken consciences, lead to a change of heart, and inspire all parties to lay down their arms and take up the path of dialogue," the AP reports. Officials and witnesses in Yemen said gunmen on Friday stormed a retirement home run by a charity established by Mother Teresa, moving room to room handcuffing the victims before shooting them in the head. The pope sent prayers for the dead and expressed his spiritual closeness to those affected by this "this act of senseless and diabolical violence." The Vatican said two of the nuns killed were Rwandan, one was Indian, and one was from Kenya. The nuns were from the Missionaries of Charity congregation, which runs the home and was founded in Calcutta by Mother Teresa. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, though Yemeni officials have blamed so-called Islamic State. In a statement, the Vatican said two of the nuns killed were Rwandan, one was Indian, and one was from Kenya. "He sends the assurance of his prayers

– A Northern California mother accused of grabbing a 12-year-old boy by the throat while confronting him about bullying her daughter may have targeted the wrong child. Delia Garcia-Bratcher, 30, came to an elementary school around lunchtime Friday and asked her son, who also attends the school, to point out her daughter's alleged tormentor, the Sonoma County Sheriff's office said in a statement, per the AP. The mother grabbed the boy by the throat in front of a number of children, the statement said. No adult saw the confrontation, and Garcia-Bratcher apparently had not checked in with the school office before coming on campus. The young witnesses later told a deputy the mother threatened the boy about bullying her daughter. The staff at Olivet Charter Elementary School took photos of red marks on the boy's neck as soon as they learned about the alleged assault, authorities said. Garcia-Bratcher was arrested on a charge of felony child abuse. She was released from jail after posting a $30,000 bail. A telephone number for a Delia Bratcher was disconnected. But on a Facebook page that said it belonged to Bratcher, she posted that she was hurt by the accusation and asserted that "the truth will be told." Lt. Mark Essick

– Elephants, already smart creatures, can tell the difference between human languages and their own, the AP reports via a new study. Researchers in Kenya played recordings of voices—some local Maasai men, some young Kamba men, female Maasai speakers, and others—to elephants, and found that the elephants reacted in the same way. The Maasai men said the same phrase, "Look, look over there, a group of elephants is coming," and the elephants tended to gather together, start smelling, and move cautiously away when they heard the men. But when they heard the young Kamba men, females, or adult male Maasai voices, they didn't react in the same way. "Their response to hearing Maasai men talking was to be alert, to move away, but not to run away in total fear," a conservation biologist not involved in the study tells AFP. "It is suggesting that elephants are capable of thinking, (of) recognizing that if Maasai men are talking, they are not likely to be hunting because if they were hunting, they would be quiet." The elephants also acted the same way when recordings of lions were played, but they bunched together so that juveniles were in the center, and moved toward the sounds as if to scare the lion away.

– Russell Crowe walked out on a BBC interview yesterday after an interviewer questioned his accent in Robin Hood. The New Zealand-born actor was “a little dumbfounded that you could possibly find any Irish in that character,” interviewer Mark Lawson told Crowe. “That’s kind of ridiculous, but it’s your show,” Crowe responded. “You’ve got dead ears if you think that’s an Irish accent,” Crowe added. “I don’t get the Irish thing by the way. I don’t get it at all,” the New York Daily News reports Crowe as saying. Lawson tried to smooth things over, but Crowe refused to answer questions about whether he didn’t want to deliver some of his most famous lines in Robin Hood with an Irish accent. “I’m a little dumbfounded that you could possibly find any Irish in that character,” Crowe said. “That’s kind of ridiculous.”

– A rookie cop who shot and killed an unarmed man in a public housing project has been indicted by a grand jury in the case, the New York Daily News reports. Peter Liang, who was on duty at the Pink Houses in Brooklyn when he fired a bullet into a stairwell, was charged with manslaughter, reckless endangerment, assault, and official misconduct. "I'm glad the grand jury looked at the evidence and returned an indictment," Kimberly Ballinger, the mother of Akai Gurley's 2-year-old daughter, tells the Daily News. "I am happy, I have faith in the Brooklyn District Attorney and I thank him." Liang, who has been on the force for less than 18 months, was allegedly holding a flashlight in one hand and clutched a 9-mm Glock in his left hand, which he also used to open a door when the gun fired, according to the Daily News. Liang and his partner didn't answer the radio in the six minutes after the shooting, and they texted their union delegates instead of testifying before the grand jury, which heard from dozens of witnesses over weeks. "Unlike the case in Staten Island, this case shows the difference in a prosecutor who will respect the grand jury's role to decide probable cause, rather than attempt

– Ron and Mary Tarnowski had been missing for eight days when their son found their home empty and their Chevy Tahoe gone on July 29. Mary, 78, had been paralyzed by a stroke decades earlier, and Ron, 81, had early-stage dementia. The Duluth, Minn., couple had been caught on surveillance video at a Country Corner store near Brookston around 1pm on the day they disappeared, and their family reported them missing the next night. On Saturday, a US Border Patrol helicopter found the couple's vehicle, stuck on a swampy trail near Highway 2 in the Brookston area, about 30 miles from their home, the Washington Post reports. Ron's body was found closer to the highway, and Mary's was inside the vehicle, about 50 feet from the road. "It is with great sadness that we must report that Ron and Mary Tarnowski have been found deceased in a remote area about a mile from their hunting camp," the Find Ron and Mary Tarnowski Facebook page states. St. Louis County Sheriff's Office Sgt. Wade Rasch says it appears the couple drove off the road onto the swampy trail that was likely only used as a snowmobile trail during the winter. Rasch says it appears Ron went to get help

– A popular TV host in Pakistan is giving away babies on his show in an effort to boost ratings during the holy month of Ramadan, Reuters reports. Aamir Liaquat Hussain, 41, gave away a baby girl last month and plans to give away a baby boy this week. "If we didn't find this baby, a cat or a dog would have eaten it," he said during one broadcast. "I'm setting an example. Giving a childless couple an abandoned child." The baby girls were found by an NGO, Chhipa Welfare Association, which says it finds up to 15 abandoned babies a month. "We didn't just give the baby away. We have our own vetting procedure," the organization's head says. "This couple was already registered with us and had four or five sessions with us." But the couple didn't know they'd be given a baby when they took part in the live broadcast, and they'll have to go to a family court to adopt the child. "Pakistan wake up," one viewer wrote on the NGO's Facebook page. "Babies are not trophies to be handed to just anyone." But Hussain, described as "one of Pakistan's most popular talk-show hosts," says he

– An African-American soldier testified today at the court-martial of an Army sergeant charged in the hazing death of a fellow soldier in Afghanistan, saying the sergeant threatened to "kill me and put me in a body bag and send me home." Pvt. Marcus Merritt said Sgt. Adam Holcomb was "in my face constantly" during the assault on 19-year-old Pvt. Danny Chen, the Los Angeles Times reports. Holcomb is one of eight soldiers charged in the case. Chen killed himself a week after the assault, which involved being dragged across rocks by Holcomb for ignoring orders. Holcomb's lawyers say Chen killed himself because his immigrant parents disowned him for joining the Army instead of going to college. Chen's platoon also faced hazing before his death, including kicking him and pelting him with rocks, but none of the soldiers have been charged.

– Facebook-owned Instagram has backed down from plans to sell users' photos and give advertisers access to their data after a public outcry. Co-founder Kevin Systrom wrote in a blog post last night that the company would revert to its old privacy policy and terms of service, which it has been in effect since October 2010, to clarify its plans for the future. "Going forward, rather than obtain permission from you to introduce possible advertising products we have not yet developed, we are going to take the time to complete our plans, and then come back to our users and explain how we would like for our advertising business to work," he wrote. Instagram "has no intention of selling your photos, and we never did," he wrote. "We don't own your photos—you do." The company, which was bought for $735 million this year, also assured users that the distribution of their photos was " governed by our privacy policy, and always has been," the New York Times reports.

– New Jersey drivers who drink coffee while driving could face stiff fines and even a license suspension under a bill winding its way through the state legislature, the AP reports. Assemblyman John Wisniewski, the bill's sponsor, says the legislation is aimed at discouraging distracted driving and that he cannot imagine that a police officer would pull anyone over for drinking coffee. Current law already prohibits texting or talking without a hands-free device. The new legislation is broader and would bar "any activity unrelated to the actual operation of a motor vehicle in a manner that interferes with the safe operation of the vehicle." Wisniewski says he sponsored the bill seven months ago, but he has yet to bring it up for a vote in a committee he leads. It also never came up for a vote in the two previous legislative sessions in which he introduced similar bills. The outcry against the bill has been so strong that his inbox has filled up even more than when he proposed a 25-cent-per-gallon increase in the gas tax. Wisniewski says when he introduced the bill before, people worried he was trying to stop them from eating sandwiches while driving. "It was the 'ham sandwich bill' last time," he says. "Now it's coffee." Supporters of the bill say

– North Korea will be represented at the 2018 Winter Olympics for the first time after a pair of figure skaters qualified Friday at the Nebelhorn Trophy in Germany, the BBC reports. Ryom Tae-Ok and Kim Ju-Sik, an 18-year-old and a 25-year-old from Pyongyang, finished fifth in the free skate, good enough for one of the final qualifying spots for Pyeongchang. The International Olympic Committee has been supporting North Korean athletes in their quest to qualify, and the North Korean Olympic Committee will now make the final decision on whether to participate in Pyeongchang. The New York Times notes that North Korea boycotted the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, but has sent its women's hockey team and a taekwondo team to compete in the South. South Korean President Moon Jae-in said earlier this month that North Korean participation in Pyeongchang will "provide a very good opportunity for inter-Korean peace and reconciliation." The International Skating Union confirmed Friday that Ryom and Kim will be the first North Korean athletes to qualify for the Winter Olympics.

– Adrianne Haslet-Davis lost her left leg below the knee in the Boston Marathon bombing two years ago, but that didn't stop the professional ballroom dancer from dancing her way to the finish line. Haslet-Davis, who was at the finish line with her husband when the first bomb went off, returned to the site Tuesday as part of an online campaign highlighting her inspiring comeback, Boston.com reports. "I could do a quickstep for hours, but I couldn't run a block, but I have great trainers and I am getting more comfortable in my blade," she says. "Half of me is so SO ready to run right now!" Haslet-Davis says she'll run the 120th Boston Marathon on April 18 with her team, #AdrianneStrong, to raise funds for the Limbs for Life Foundation, which provides prosthetic limbs to people in need. "I'm going to cry the whole time," Haslet-Davis says. "For me, [the finish line] has been defined by triumph, blood, sweat, tears, and tragedy—and with victory—and everyone who crosses it crosses for a different reason for themselves. And maybe it's even a different reason from when they first cross the starting

– "Made in America" may not mean "all or virtually all" made in the US, but it can still be a great way for companies to advertise their American-made products. The Federal Trade Commission has long required that claims on products labeled "Made in USA" be "all or virtually all" made in the US, and it's not uncommon for companies to make such claims on everything from T-shirts to coffee mugs, reports the Los Angeles Times. But the FTC is now cracking down on what it calls "misleading" Made in USA claims, especially when it comes to products with phrases like "American-made" or "made in America." The agency has gone so far as to require that all products labeled "Made in USA" be marked with the name of the country of origin. "Companies that make false or misleading claims about the amount of US content in their products must comply with the FTC's Made in USA policy," the agency says in a press release. The agency has been cracking down on what it calls "misleading" Made in USA claims in recent months, including on products with phrases like "made in China" or "made in India" and on products with phrases like "made in USA" or "made

– Julia Roberts' half-sister, Nancy Motes, may have killed herself after penning a suicide note that revealed "dark secrets" about her sister, Conner Dilbeck tells the Daily Mail. Dilbeck, fiance of Motes' brother, John Dilbeck, found Motes' body in the bath Sunday, the same day Roberts was supposed to be at an Oscar nominees lunch. "We are talking about people who are powerful," Dilbeck says. "People who have very delicate power, people who are in the limelight. Their power can be destroyed very easily if they betray that power." Motes, a dog walker, had reportedly struggled with drug addiction. "If Nancy had photos and wrote a diary, describing her feelings towards her sister, he could use them," a source tells the New York Post. "There is a fear that John could be holding Nancy’s personal items hostage and possibly sell them to the highest bidder." The source adds that Roberts and their mother "felt that he was a bad influence" on Motes.

– Anthony Scaramucci's first tweet as White House communications director was a warning to the FBI. "In light of the leak of my financial disclosure info which is a felony. I will be contacting the FBI and the Justice Department," Scaramucci wrote, tagging White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus. Scaramucci did not specify what information was leaked, but a Politico article cited the incoming communications director's required financial disclosure in reporting he earned $4.9 million since last year from his ownership stake in investment firm SkyBridge. Scaramucci appeared to delete the tweet, but in a subsequent post said Priebus was among the senior White House officials helping to crack down on leaks. Scaramucci's financial disclosure form, which is publicly available upon request, values SkyBridge at more than $50 million and states that he owns nearly 44% of the company. When the sale of the company is completed, expected to be in the third quarter of this year, he will receive "the agreed-upon purchase price for his share of the sale proceeds," according to the filing. "It's black and white that he's going to get money," said Austin Evers, executive director at American Oversight, a watchdog group that focuses on transparency in

– Bernie Sanders is not going to be Hillary Clinton's running mate, sources tell CNN and the New York Times. The Times' sources say Clinton told Sanders at a private meeting Tuesday night that she has decided not to pick him as her running mate. Sanders, who has not officially conceded the race to Clinton, was not expecting to be considered as Clinton's vice president and he doesn't view her decision as a slight, the sources say. Another source close to Sanders tells CNN that he would risk being seen as a sell-out by his supporters if he joined the Clinton ticket.

– "This study is really a wake-up call to the medical community that a relatively large number of colorectal cancers are occurring in young people," says senior study author Dr. Samantha Hendren of the University of Michigan, whose research is published in the journal Cancer. A study of 258,000 patients diagnosed with colon and rectal cancers between 1998 and 2011 found that about 15% of them were younger than 50, reports Reuters. That means that by 2030, nearly one in four rectal tumors and more than one in 10 colon cancers will be diagnosed in people under 50. "Colorectal cancer has traditionally been thought of as a disease of the elderly; this study is really a wake-up call to the medical community that a relatively large number of colorectal cancers are occurring in young people," Hendren tells the New York Times. The researchers say the results suggest that it's time for the medical community to start paying more attention to the younger set of patients, who are more likely to be diagnosed with tumors that have spread to other organs or that have metastasized, meaning the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. Younger patients with tumors that have spread to the lymph nodes were 30% more likely to be diagnosed with that cancer, and 50% more likely to have cancer

– "It would sound like someone drove into your house, but as far as we know it didn't cause any damage," Justin Schultz, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Sullivan, Wis., tells the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. On Tuesday night, some residents in southern Wisconsin called in to report a "frostquake," a seismic event that occurs when water that drains into the ground freezes, expands, and places stress on the surrounding ground. "The fracturing of the soil and rock creates the frostquake," Schultz says. "This one was maybe a brief rumbling, but a very loud boom was the primary characteristic of this frostquake." According to Schultz, Wisconsin is among the states where frostquakes are relatively common. "Of all the states that have reported cryoseisms, Wisconsin is among them," he says. The Wisconsin Air National Guard will be conducting training flights at night Monday through Thursday, the Journal Sentinel reports. Residents are being warned that F-16 fighter jets will be taking off and landing until about 10pm.

– Japanese officials are considering burying the country's damaged nuclear reactors under sand and concrete in a last-ditch effort to avert a catastrophic meltdown. Experts say burying the plants would be the only way to prevent a meltdown as bad as Three Mile Island's in 1979, Reuters reports. The situation at the Fukushima Dai-ichi plant is now rated at level 5, the same as the 1986 Chernobyl disaster, but officials say it is at least as bad as Three Mile Island. In another development, engineers attached a power cable to the outside of the plant today in a race to prevent deadly radiation from an accident now rated at least as bad as America's Three Mile Island incident in 1979. Further cabling inside was under way before an attempt to restart water pumps needed to cool overheated nuclear fuel rods. If that works, it will be a turning point. "If they are successful in getting the cooling infrastructure up and running, that will be a significant step forward in establishing stability," said a nuclear power expert at US-based FocalPoint Consulting Group. Meanwhile, officials say radiation levels in Tokyo are not harmful, but the city has seen an exodus of tourists, expatriates, and many Japanese, who fear a blast of radioactive material. "I'm leaving because my parents are terrified.

– A former postal worker in New Jersey who masterminded a scheme to steal money orders from the US Postal Service has been sentenced to five years in prison. Eugene Bowen, 36, of Knoxville, Tenn., was also sentenced to three years of supervised release and ordered to pay restitution of $18,470 after pleading guilty to transmitting and presenting unlawfully issued USPS money orders with intent to defraud the United States, US Attorney Craig Carpenito said in a statement, per the Philadelphia Inquirer. According to court documents, Marc Saunders, 40, of Sicklerville, NJ, a former employee at the New Lisbon post office, provided Bowen with stolen money orders and told him to recruit others to cash them. Bowen admitted to recruiting people to cash the orders and keeping the rest of the money for Saunders and himself. In addition to the prison term, a federal judge has sentenced the last of three accomplices to prison, ordering Anthony Bell, 39, of Philadelphia, to spend a year and a day in custody for his role in the 15-month scheme. The third accomplice, Andre Sutton, 39, of Knoxville, was sentenced to nine months in prison. All three accomplices were ordered to pay restitution to the Postal Service of almost $100,000. (A former postal worker in Florida says he

– It's that time of year again: the "sober January" challenge, in which people try to refrain from drinking for a month. It's a seductive idea, writes one columnist in the Guardian, but it's "actually a terrible idea, rooted in guilt rather than science." For him, it was a sober January. "I managed several sober Januarys and they became an important weapon in my armoury of denial," he writes. "Me, an alcoholic? Hardly! How could I manage to stay off drink for a month if I was?" For others, it's a sign that they have a problem. "The only mates that I could persuade to do a sober January with me were the ones who were as bad as or worse than me," he writes. "The normals, like my co-worker, were never interested. Why would they be? If you are worried about the amount you have been drinking, the answer is not to swear off drink for a month." Click for his full column.

– Someone in Romania thought he'd made a buck selling an old typewriter at a flea market—but he was wrong. The "typewriter" turned out to be a German Wehrmacht Enigma I cipher machine used by the Nazi military during World War II, and it sold for $51,500 at auction Tuesday, Reuters reports. The collector who bought it for just 100 euros (about $114) "is a cryptography professor and ... he knew very well what he was buying," says the collectible consignment manager at Artmark, which sold the machine to an unnamed online bidder. The Enigma machine was used to encrypt messages sent by the German military, but it was a British team of cryptologists called Bletchley Park's code-breaking team that shortened the war by at least two years, CNN reports. (The team's work is credited with shortening the war.)

– For the first time, scientists have successfully harvested stem cells from cloned human embryos, a breakthrough that could lead to new treatments for diseases like Parkinson's and diabetes, the AP reports. Scientists have tried to get stem cells from cloned human embryos for about a decade, but they've failed generally because the embryos stopped developing before producing the cells. In 2004, a South Korean scientist claimed to have gotten stem cells from cloned human embryos, but that turned out to be a fraud. In today's edition of Cell, researchers in Oregon report harvesting stem cells from six embryos created from donated eggs. Two embryos had been given DNA from skin cells of a child with a genetic disorder, and the others had DNA from fetal skin cells. Dr. George Daley, a stem cell expert at Children's Hospital Boston who didn't participate in the work, called the new results "one landmark step in a very long journey" toward creating DNA-matched transplant tissue. Now, Daley says, scientists must compare the embryo-cloning approach with another technology that reprograms blood or skin cells directly into substitutes for embryonic stem cells. This reprogramming approach is technically simpler and doesn't involve embryos or require the donation of human eggs, and it was widely acclaimed when it was reported in

– A "Mission Impossible"-style heist in London has stolen more than $3 million worth of rare books, including works by Galileo, Leonardo da Vinci, and Isaac Newton. Police say thieves broke into a warehouse near Heathrow Airport between Jan. 29 and Jan. 30 and stole more than 160 rare books, including a 1566 edition of De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium by Copernicus and a 1506 edition of Dante's Divine Comedy, the Independent reports. A list of stolen books published by the International League of Antiquarian Booksellers shows the most valuable stolen book is a 1656 edition of Galileo's On the Revolutions of the Heavenly Spheres. "It was clearly a robbery done to order," the owner of a rare Copernicus book stolen in the raid tells the Mail on Sunday. "It was a specialized gang. They took only books, nothing else." The books were being stored in the warehouse while they were being shipped to the California International Antiquarian Book Fair, which runs from Jan. 30 to Feb. 1. A source tells the Mail on Sunday that the thieves checked the contents of the containers against a list, "throwing the ones they didn't want away." The books were then placed into holdalls and pulled them onto the

– Donald Trump says Jeff Bezos is using the Washington Post "as a toy" to try to influence corporate tax policy. "Every hour we're getting calls from reporters from the Washington Post asking ridiculous questions," Trump told Fox News' Sean Hannity on Thursday, per USA Today. "And I will tell you, this is owned as a toy by Jeff Bezos ... Amazon is getting away with murder, tax-wise. He's using The Washington Post for power so that the politicians in Washington don't tax Amazon like they should be taxed." Trump said Bezos thinks "I'll go after him for antitrust because he's controlling so much, Amazon is controlling so much of what they are doing. He's using The Washington Post, which is peanuts, he's using that for political purposes to save Amazon in terms of taxes and in terms of antitrust." Post associate editor Bob Woodward told the National Association of Realtors convention Wednesday that more than 20 reporters are investigating Bezos' life, including his real estate deals in New York, which he says is "more complex than the CIA." "We're going to do a book, we're doing articles about every phase of his life," Woodward said. "He thinks I'll go after him for

– Reddit users have been posting nude photos of celebrities—including Jennifer Lawrence, Kate Upton, and dozens of other A-listers—on the site's "Reddit The Fappening" since the photos first surfaced over the weekend, and now Reddit administrators say they're considered child porn. Lawyers for gymnast McKayla Maroney have confirmed that the photos, which were shared on a popular Reddit forum called r/TheFappening, were taken while the gymnast was underage, Mashable reports. Maroney's lawyers have sent a letter to Porn.com and other websites, demanding that the photos be removed. Reddit administrators say that if they don't remove the photos, "this subreddit will most likely be banned, very quickly." Meanwhile, Reddit users have been posting revenge-porn photos of actress Liz Lee, whose nude photos were not part of the initial leaks, but were taken by her boyfriend when she was 16. Lee's lawyers have also confirmed that the photos were taken when she was underage. Meanwhile, Redditors have been donating to a cause that's close to Lawrence's heart: the Prostate Cancer Foundation, Gawker reports. A post on r/TheFappening, which is now the main

– Avengers: Infinity War is still ruling the box office in its third weekend in theaters, the AP reports. The Walt Disney Studios on Sunday estimates it has added $61.8 million from North American theaters, bringing its total domestic earnings to $547.8 million. Globally the film has now grossed over $1.6 billion, making it the fifth biggest of all time. The superhero blockbuster easily overpowered newcomers like the Melissa McCarthy comedy Life of the Party and the Gabrielle Union thriller Breaking In. In a distant second, Life of the Party earned an estimated $18.5 million, while the modestly budgeted Breaking In took third place with $16.5 million. The mom-themed films were strategically timed to launch over Mother's Day weekend. Both drew mostly female audiences. "It's great to see a female-led, action-packed thriller doing so well at the domestic box office this Mother's Day weekend," says a Universal exec. "We have an amazing partner in Will Packer. He constantly delivers quality titles that audiences cannot get enough of." The second weekend of Lionsgate and Pantelion's comedy Overboard landed in fourth with $10 million, while the sixth weekend of Paramount's A Quiet Place secured No. 5 with $6.3 million.

– Police have found the bodies of eight babies buried in the garden of two homes in northern France, in the fifth case of multiple infanticide reported in the country since 2003. The mother, Dominique Cottrez, 45, has admitted to hiding her pregnancies, and to killing the babies—two of whom she hid in the family freezer—from her husband, Pierre-Marie, 47, who was "dumbstruck" by the news, the Guardian reports. The couple was arrested after a neighbor found two bodies in the backyard of a house owned by Dominique's parents. The neighbor also found the bodies of a third baby in the backyard of a house owned by Pierre-Marie's parents. Cottrez has told investigators that she hid her pregnancies from her husband, who she says was "dumbstruck" by the news, but has not been charged with the murders. Experts say that in many cases, women in similar situations to Cottrez are suffering from "pregnancy denial," a mental condition in which a woman does not realize that she is pregnant and does not want children. "Women can carry on menstruating, they don't put on weight, and their breasts don't get bigger because the denial is so strong it overcomes the physical manifestations

– President Trump and first lady Melania Trump arrived in Tel Aviv, Israel, Monday on the second stop of their eight-day tour to five countries, the Washington Post reports. As the Trumps walked away from Air Force One on the Tel Aviv tarmac, the president was seen reaching for his wife's hand. She then appeared to be swatting the president's hand away. Israeli newspaper Haaretz shared a clip of the moment. The "flinch" sparked curiosity in Twitter users after the video was shared specifically to point out her reaction. The caption says, Literally even the slightest touch by that garbage monster makes her flinch. Literally even the slightest touch by that garbage monster makes her flinch." Some Twitter users are saying it's the "very first abuse red flag." Others say it "Speaks volumes about their relationship." Meanwhile, the Los Angeles Times reports that Melania Trump is "unhappy" in the White House. "They don't know what their jeopardy is. They don't know what they're looking at. They don't know if they're a part of a conspiracy that might unfold. They don't know whether to hire lawyers or not, how they're going to pay for them if they do.

– The Australian government has come up with what it says is the world's ugliest color to discourage people from smoking: Pantone 448 C, also known as an "opaque couché" or "drab, dark brown." The color was chosen after three months of research and mockups by the research agency GfK, which was hired by the government to find a color that would be so "reprehensible" on tobacco packaging that it would dissuade people from smoking, reports the Wall Street Journal. Australia is the latest country to adopt "plain packaging" laws, along with the UK, Ireland, and France, which have all used mockups of the same murky color. The color was chosen after multiple studies showed that it would make people think twice about smoking, per the Australian government's website. Australia's health minister tells the Australian Broadcasting Corporation that the new color will be on all cigarette packaging by the end of the year. (The US, UK, and France have also adopted "plain packaging" laws.)

– The Chicago Cubs beat the Cleveland Indians 5-1 Wednesday night to even the World Series at one game each. One of the few bright spots for the Cubs was the play of Kyle Schwarber, who not only returned from a devastating knee injury in time to play in the World Series but has become the team's "legend," reports USA Today. "I can't even describe what he's doing right now," says Cubs third baseman Kris Bryant. "No one's ever seen anything like it." Schwarber, who tore two knee ligaments in April and didn't play again until mid-June, is hitting .429 in the Series with two doubles, a walk, and two runs. "He better not take one single swing in the offseason," says first baseman Anthony Rizzo. "He's just a dirt bag," Rizzo says. "He's always around the field. He's always watching baseball. Always watching film. Sometimes, too much." Schwarber met his 10-year-old friend, Campbell Faulkner, who has a rare form of mitochondrial disease, during spring training and saw him in the World Series. "That's why we're calling it 'The Legend of Kyle Schwarber,'

– Cassie Young, a 31-year-old digital director for the nationally syndicated radio show The Bert Show, got engaged last week, and she received a message from a personal trainer offering to help her "shape up" for the big day. "Congratulations on your engagement," wrote the man. "Hire me to help you get in shape for your wedding." Young replied, "I am in shape! Thank you so much for the offer, though." The man replied, "I know you want to look your best on your wedding day. If you don't hire me, hire someone. Those pictures last centuries. Your children's children's children will still have those pictures." Young replied, "I know it's probably hard for you to understand this, but it's taken me a long time to love my body. I'm constantly shamed or reminded that I'm heavy and I should be embarrassed—or people are embarrassed for me—or just straight up rude, calling me 'disgusting.'" The man replied, "You can accept how you look but you can't be happy with the way you look. You can't lie to yourself. ... I just wish the whole big body acceptance people would accept the fact

– If you're a Disney nerd who's looking for a partner, Mousemingle.com might be just the site for you. "Niche dating sites are more common these days," founder Dave Tavres tells Mashable. "There's a dating site for pot lovers and JDate for Jewish people. The first time I saw Farmers Only I thought it was a Saturday Night Live sketch." But Mousemingle is different, he says. "All the normal sites don't have Disney questions." Instead, Mousemingle asks users to check a few boxes: favorite Disney songs, Disney shopping habits, and "Disney nerd level." "I'm not the guy who hits on women at the park, and there's no flag that says, 'hey I'm single,'" Tavres says. "I found it hard to find women who were as interested in Disney as I am." Mousemingle charges $12.55 a month, and Tavres hopes people "literally around the world will find the site useful," he says. – Moses Malone died yesterday in Virginia at the age of 60, and the sports world is paying tribute to the Philadelphia 76ers great. Here's what people are saying: "When I think of Moses, besides the numbers and the great player, he was a great person," former Sixers point guard Maurice Cheeks tells the Philadelphia Inquirer. "I can still hear it. He would still tease me about pancakes. We had a noon game one time in Milwaukee and Moses was a little late coming down from his room. He saw me eating pancakes and asked me for some. I said no and he couldn't believe it. He teased me for years about those pancakes. I said no and he couldn't believe it." "When we got him, we knew all about him," former Sixers head coach Billy Cunningham tells the Philadelphia Inquirer. "He was an MVP. He had great numbers. But we didn't know who he was. Well, it didn't take long for us to mesh with him on the court, and it certainly didn't take long to love him off of it, too. When I think of Moses, besides the numbers and the great player, he was a great person. I just think of that laugh."

JERUSALEM — New archaeological tests have confirmed that the site many Christians believe to be the tomb of Jesus Christ dates back 1,700 years to A.D. 325, the same era when the Romans first identified the place as holy.                  � With invasions, fires and even earthquakes occurring at Jerusalem's Church of the Holy Sepulchre over the centuries, historians had questioned whether the tomb had been destroyed or moved. ¯¯¯¯ � When the tomb was opened on the night of October 26, 2016, scientists were surprised by what they found beneath the marble cladding: an older, broken marble slab incised with a cross, resting directly atop the original limestone surface of the "burial bed." � � Some researchers speculated that this older slab may have been laid down in the Crusader period, while others offered an earlier date, suggesting that it may have already been in place and broken when the church was destroyed in 1009.No one, however, was ready to claim that this might be the first physical evidence for the earliest Roman shrine on the site.The Roman temple was razed and excavations beneath it revealed a tomb hewn from a limestone cave.The top of the cave was sheared off to expose the interior

In recent years, the industry of distilled spirits has put out a call for new beverages with different flavors created from unusual raw materials. To answer this call, some scientists examined the potential of used coffee grounds. The scientists first collected this raw material from a Portuguese coffee roasting company and dried it. Then they heated the powder in water at 163°C for 45 minutes, separated out the liquid, and added sugar. Next, the team mixed in yeast cells, let the concoction ferment, and concentrated the sample to get a higher alcohol content. (A similar process is used to produce other distilled beverages such as whiskey and rum from wheat and molasses.) And voilà! Used coffee grounds produced a new alcoholic beverage with 40% ethanol, comparable to other hard liquor such as vodka and tequila, researchers will report in the September issue of LWT - Food Science and Technology. To evaluate the product, eight trained taste testers were brought in and rated the intensity of different smells and flavors in the alcohol. The judges described the drink as smelling like coffee and tasting bitter and pungent. Researchers noted that the taste could be improved with age and concluded that the quality was good enough for consumption. Don’t count on the caffeine to keep you awake, however;

The University of Michigan study raises questions about the current guidelines to begin screening at age 50.                                   Signs of colorectal cancer, often called the “symptomless cancer,” include anemia, a dramatic change in the size or frequency of bowel movements, and dark blood or blood mixed with stool, (sometimes appearing as black threads), in bowel movements. Because these symptoms may be nonexistent, mild, or infrequent, many people are not aware of their condition until their malignancy becomes advanced and spreads into the lymph nodes. A colonoscopy is the usual screening test, but stool tests are also effective for some people. AFTER THE 76ERS had acquired Julius Erving before the 1976-77 season, the team went on a run of being eliminated in the NBA Finals three times and the Eastern Conference Finals twice in a six-year span. While those teams were composed of other star-level players such as Doug Collins, George McGinnis, Bobby Jones, Darryl Dawkins and Lloyd Free, to name a few, there was an ingredient missing. Billy Cunningham, who took over as head coach before the 1977-78 season, knew exactly what it was. "What we needed was that physical presence," Cunningham said yesterday. "As good as Darryle and Caldwell Jones were, they weren't able to take us to the next level. With Doc [Erving] and Bobby Jones and the others, we had great athletes. We needed exactly what we got."                  �士 What the Sixers got in the summer of 1982 was Moses Malone, the player everyone thought could take the organization to the promised land. He delivered, carrying the team to its only title since the 1967 season.
